titleStmt.title: The hype is over-hyped: An experimental evaluation of how mindfulness hype and the uncertainty of programme benefits impact participation

analytic.title: The hype is over-hyped: An experimental evaluation of how mindfulness hype and the uncertainty of programme benefits impact participation

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Mindfulness-based programmes (MBPs) are widely used to support employees' wellbeing, despite little evidence that MBPs are more effective than other programmes. MBPs are often promoted to solve a plethora of challenges, potentially creating a 'mindfulness hype'. To inform more balanced communication strategies, a 2x2 experiment (N=669) evaluated whether decisions to participate in a hypothetical wellbeing programme were impacted by (1) programme name containing the word 'mindfulness', to quantify the 'hype' effect, and/or (2) presenting uncertainty around beneficial effects. Participants expressed similar interest in participating in both programmes, (p = .318, partial η 2 = .002). Conveying uncertainty by presenting a range (rather than exact percentage) for anticipated improvement did not reduce participant ratings of the likelihood of participating (p = .788, partial η 2 < .001). The results do not support the presence of 'mindfulness hype'. There is a need to better understand how uncertainty regarding programme effectiveness affects decision-making.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Many jurisdictions use restrictions and regulations to balance protecting and promoting population health and creating economic circumstances for companies to flourish.

Limitations are placed on the content and placement of advertisements for products which might cause direct harms to health, for example, alcohol and tobacco (e.g., in the European Union, Australia, New Zealand) or for junk food marketed targeted toward children (e.g., Mexico, Taiwan, Canada). However, with commercially available wellbeing programmes or, in some countries, pharmaceutical interventions, advertisers often enjoy the freedom to sell their products with the means they see fit. Such marketing is effective: direct-to-consumer advertising has been shown to increase the demand for antidepressants (Arney & Menjivar, 2014;Boschert, 2011;Meyerhoefer & Zuvekas, 2008). By contrast, health professionals are governed by treatment guidelines when suggesting or prescribing programmes and treatments for help-seekers (e.g., National Institute for Health and Care Excellence guidelines in the United Kingdom, Clinical Practice Guidelines in the United States of America). These guidelines consider the effectiveness as well as the risks of interventions. When it comes to commercially available wellbeing programmes, the responsibility for the selection falls to the purchaser (i.e., an individual consumer, or an employer seeking to offer a programme enmasse to employees) who may not have the skills or time to evaluate scientific evidence of a programme's effectiveness, particularly in circumstances where persuasive marketing techniques are effective and unrestricted. It is thus important to understand how these techniques influence members of the public to take part in wellbeing programmes. Better understanding will aid science communication by enabling a more balanced strategy to counter inflated effectiveness claims (Lewandowsky & van der Linden, 2021), helping consumers to make better-informed decisions when considering wellbeing programmes.

There is evidence that improving communication of in one health domain could impact another: evidence-based information about cancer screening offered to the public has been shown to reduce the impact of non-evidence-based screening recommendations (Wegwarth et al., 2017). Here, we explore two factors that might influence user decisions to participate in a wellbeing programme; whether the programme was labelled as 'mindfulness', and the communicated uncertainty around beneficial effects.

Mindfulness-based programmes (MBPs) are popular for supporting wellbeing. Programmes claiming to train mindfulness skills are sometimes perceived as a panacea, leading to a 'mindfulness hype' (Oman, 2023;Van Dam et al., 2017), and creating a lucrative multi-million dollar global market despite lack of evidence that MBPs outperform other wellbeing programmes (Galante et al., 2021;Vainre et al., 2024). The label "mindfulness" itself may be contributing to efficacy through expectancy effects: there is evidence that, keeping other aspects of an intervention the same, the intervention labelled "mindful" could be more effective compared to the same intervention without the label (Davies et al., 2022;Ghanbari Noshari et al., 2023). This effect is often conceptualised as 'mindfulness hype'.

Such hype could boost the uptake of thousands of so-called mindfulness programmes that consist of broad selection of meditation practices, which differ in the conceptualisation of mindfulness skills and intervention logic (Crane, 2019;Crane et al., 2017;Crane & Hecht, 2018;Oman, 2023;Van Dam et al., 2017). The programmes therefore vary in their content (Crane, 2019;Crane & Hecht, 2018), duration (Van Dam et al., 2017) and teacher training (Crane & Hecht, 2018;Kenny et al., 2020). Given the high number of interventions on offer, the public is likely to face challenges in distinguishing programmes that can be defined as mindfulness-based programmes (Crane et al., 2017) from interventions that have little to do with mindfulness. The latter is a mixed group of interventions for which effectiveness is difficult to predict; they might equate meditation or binaural beats with mindfulness or define mindfulness as focusing solely on positive emotions. Such differences have important implications (Galante & Van Dam, 2024). The following example illustrates this: While there is little doubt that physical activity has physical and mental health benefits, not everything labelled sport or athletics has comparable health outcomes. Someone taking up armchair athletics to improve their muscle tone is likely to be disappointed. Indeed, it is difficult to imagine that anyone would start watching sports for this purpose. When it comes to mindfulness, however, public knowledge is less nuanced and marketing could be effective in persuading consumers to spend their resources on interventions that are the mindfulness equivalent of armchair athletics. The disappointment in the lack of benefits could erode trust in other wellbeing interventions (whether mindfulness-based or not) inhibiting their uptake regardless of superior evidence-base (Birtwistle et al., 2019;Ward, 2017).
Similarly, willingness to procure MBPs may be influenced by their proclaimed success.
Providers frequently advertise point-estimates of the effectiveness of their intervention.

BeMindful suggests it reduces depression by 63% (Be Mindful, n.d.); Headspace reports that 85% of its partner organisations found their program helpful for employees with common mental health problems (Headspace, n.d.). Such point-estimates sound impressive but are bound to be inaccurate due to epistemic uncertainty -limitations in our knowledge due to lack of research or inconclusive results (van der Bles et al., 2019). Although there are widely used frameworks to evaluate the certainty of evidence (e.g., Guyatt et al., 2008), the communication is intended for academic audiences and is rarely conveyed to decision makers (for a discussion, see Blastland et al., 2020). Although when it is, the decision makers appreciate it (Wardekker et al., 2008). Communication of the uncertainty around pointestimates is important to ensure that the effect of MBPs is realistically represented and not over-estimated by consumers and procurers.

Drawing from literature in other fields, notably climate change and science communication, we can hypothesise that communicating the epistemic uncertainty of an effect could play an important role in decisions to join or commission an MBP (e.g., Galvão & Mitchell, 2021;Han, 2013;Jenkins et al., 2019;Padilla et al., 2021;Savelli & Joslyn, 2013;Wintle et al., 2019).

However, the research to date is not immediately applicable to the context of communicating the effects of MBPs. First, health and wellbeing communication has predominantly focused on point probabilities, i.e., how to effectively convey the probability of a specific, often binary, outcome (Han et al., 2011;Kalke et al., 2021). Little is known about how to convey imprecision around the given probability (Han et al., 2011;Kalke et al., 2021) or in circumstances where an outcome is measured on a ratio scale (percentage of improvement). Such imprecision is not necessarily too complex for lay audience: there is evidence to suggest human brains are more adapted to decision making in contexts where some information is unknown or unknowable (Volz & Gigerenzer, 2012). Second, to date, experiments investigating the effects of uncertainty in data on decision-making have primarily focussed on the probability of threatening events (e.g., death, extreme weather conditions), where there is a high cost of loss (e.g., Gustafson & Rice, 2019;Jenkins et al., 2019;Kalke et al., 2021;Padilla et al., 2021;Savelli & Joslyn, 2013). In the case of MBPs, the context is not risk of a loss but the chances of a gain: a positive mental health outcome. This distinction is important. Given equal amounts of uncertainty of the effect, losses (probability of adverse effects) are likely to be weighed more than gains (probability of beneficial effects) (Tversky & Kahneman, 1974, 1981, 2000. This bias may be exacerbated by context as small probabilities (e.g., health risks related to a treatment) are likely to be overestimated and higher probabilities (e.g., treatment's health benefits) underestimated (Tversky & Kahneman, 1992). This differentiation limits the application of literature on the communication of uncertainty, and more specifically ambiguity, to decision making regarding wellbeing programmes such as MBPs.

div.head: Aims of the study
div.p: Attempting to quantify the mindfulness "hype effect", we first aimed to determine whether a programme entitled mindfulness would lead to increased willingness to participate in the programme. Second, we aimed to understand whether communicating uncertainty around the possible benefits of an MBPs would reduce its attractiveness. Our primary hypotheses were that a) participants would rate the likelihood of joining the programme named mindfulness higher compared to a control wellbeing programme of the same effectiveness; and b) participants would rate the likelihood of joining the programme with no uncertainty communicated higher than the programme that explicitly stated uncertainty about outcomes. Our secondary hypothesis was of an interaction effect between the uncertainty and programme type, such that the presentation of uncertainty had a greater effect in the mindfulness condition relative to the control condition.

div.head: Participants and recruitment
div.p: We recruited participants through Prolific and social media. Participants were eligible to join the study if they were a) at least 18 years of age and b) currently working at least 0.2 fulltime equivalent (greater than or equal to 8 hours) for one employer, given that the advert was for a workplace-based programme (i.e., would hypothetically be completed on work time and paid for by the employer). The participants were paid 10 AUD/currency equivalent for their time.

div.head: Sample size
div.p: Power analysis to detect our hypothesised main effects was conducted using the Superpower Shiny App (Lakens & Caldwell, 2021). The smallest effect size of interest for the programme effect was set at Cohen's d = 0.35 while the smallest effect size of interest for the uncertainty effect was Cohen's d = -0.25. We set the alpha at 0.05. With 105 participants per cell, we estimated to have at least power of 0.80 for the main effects. We thus decided to recruit a minimum of 420 participants in total.

div.head: Materials and procedure
div.p: We aimed to simulate a situation where a consumer needs to decide whether to join a wellbeing programme after being exposed to an advertisement. Participants were presented with a brief wellbeing programme description featuring its aims, content, and anticipated outcomes. The programme description manipulated the following: a) whether the programme was called a 'Mindfulness Wellbeing Program' or simply a 'Wellbeing Program'. and b) presentation of the uncertainty of the effect of the wellbeing programme (17% vs 5-35% improvement). In other aspects, the programme descriptions remained as similar as possible (e.g., aims, outcomes, time commitment), the grammar and syntax permitting. The used adverts are provided in Materials (https://osf.io/ubxg5). After studying the description, participants completed a survey designed to capture the dependent variables and covariates.

The experiment was set up in Qualtrics (Qualtrics, 2021). Participants were randomised using simple randomisation to one of the programmes and one of the uncertainty scenarios using Qualtrics's in-built randomiser element. This way, the randomisation process was automatic and concealed from researchers.

div.head: Willingness to join the programme
div.p: The primary outcome was a single-item question on willingness to join the described programme: "What is the likelihood you would join this programme?" rated on a 100-point Likert scale ("I definitely would not take part" to "I definitely would take part).

div.head: Previous experiences with self-improvement programmes and with mindfulness programmes
div.p: To index likely covariates, we asked respondents to report whether they had taken previously part in workplace-based self-improvement, health, or wellbeing programmes. Those responding "yes" were asked to indicate in which types of programmes they had participated. Where participants reported they had taken mindfulness or other contemplative practice programmes, we asked the length of lifetime experience with meditation in hours.

Finally, we asked all respondents (regardless of their self-reported experience with mindfulness programmes), whether mindfulness was a common practice in their community (100-point scale, definitely not…definitely yes).

div.head: Manipulation checks
div.p: As a manipulation check (for wellbeing programme type), to better understand what techniques (i.e., stress reduction, mindfulness, time management, emotion regulation, relaxation) the participants thought the advertised wellbeing programme contained, we asked participants to indicate the share of each technique in percentages. The sum of all five techniques could not be more than 100 but could be lower. This question was added after pre-registration of the experimental design.

div.head: Sample and workplace features
div.p: To be able to describe the sample, we asked participants to provide information on their gender, ethnicity, job status, company size, type of work, and industry. We also asked participants to indicate to what extent they thought the advertised programme would reduce stress (100-point scale, definitely would not reduce stress…definitely would reduce stress).

div.head: Statistical models
div.p: For the main analysis, we had pre-registered a 2x2 ANCOVA. However, we found that some ANCOVA assumptions (normality of residuals and linearity between covariate and outcome variables) were not met and thus, we additionally completed bootstrapped ANCOVA and included non-linear terms to check the robustness of our ANCOVA model results. As preregistered, prior exposure to mindfulness was added as covariate. Below we report the results from the pre-registered model as this model agreed with the bootstrapped ANCOVA model.

div.head: Changes compared to the pre-registration
div.p: We made changes to the exclusion criteria. The pre-registration stated we would exclude participants who completed the study in under 5 minutes. At study conclusion, the mean completion time indicated that we had overestimated how long the study would take to complete. Thus, we revised this to exclude those who completed the study in less than one minute, however, no one was excluded on this basis. We also excluded participants who failed the two attention checks (n = 1) and those we suspected to be bots or fraudulent (n = 596).

div.head: Participants
div.p: After initial recruitment, identified cases of suspected bots and frauds were removed. We also excluded participants who did not fulfil the inclusion criteria (worked less than 8 hours per week, failed both attention checks, and those with missing outcome or covariate data (see Figure 1). The final dataset thus contained 665 participants, aged from 18 to 77 years (M = 36.85,SD = 11.45). See Table 1 for the breakdown of participants demographics and characteristics. hours, and 8 (1.20%) reported more than 5000 hours of mediation over their lifetime.

div.head: Manipulation checks
div.p: To test whether our first manipulation of program type (mindfulness, n = 336; versus wellbeing, n = 326) was successful, we compared the extent to which the participants thought the advertised programme contained mindfulness techniques. Between subjects ttest results indicated that participants in the mindfulness condition (M = 48.32,SD = 28.88) perceived their advertised programme to consist of a higher degree of mindfulness techniques relative to those in the wellbeing condition (M = 36.33, SD = 24.15), t(645.96) = 5.80, p < .001 d=0.45. We did not observe any statistically significant difference in amount of anticipated stress reduction between the mindfulness (M = 57.11, SD = 23.76) and wellbeing group (M = 58.24, SD = 21.05), t(656.63) =-0.65, p = .516, d=0.05.

div.head: Primary analyses
div.p: Across all conditions, the average likelihood of joining the advertised program was 65.33%

(SD = 28.36). As pre-registered, we completed a two-way ANCOVA model to determine whether the likelihood of joining the program was predicted by program type (mindfulness or wellbeing), uncertainty of the effect size within the advertisement (uncertain or certain), and the interaction between program type and uncertainty, while adjusting for prior experience with meditation as a covariate. We did not find evidence for the main effect of program type; F(1,656) = 1.00, p = .318, partial η 2 = .002, nor uncertainty F(1,656) = 0.07, p = .788, partial η 2 < .001 in predicting likelihood of joining the program. There was also no evidence for an interaction between program type and uncertainty F(1,656) = 0.02, p = .890, partial η 2 < .001. Across all participants, prior experience with meditation significantly predicted likelihood of participating in the advertised program F(5,656) = 4.01, p = .001, partial η 2 = .03, such that prior lifetime experience with mindfulness increased the likelihood of joining the program.

div.head: DISCUSSION
div.p: By attempting to quantify the factors which influence consumer decision making within a controlled experimental environment, this study aimed to inform public-facing communication regarding mindfulness-based programmes. Contrary to hypotheses, we found no evidence for a mindfulness hype effect. Similarly, conveying uncertainty did not reduce participants' ratings of the likelihood of joining a wellbeing programme. There was also no evidence for an interaction between wellbeing programme type and uncertainty of the effect.

The lack of mindfulness hype effect is surprising given mindfulness has become a buzzword (Galante & Van Dam, 2024;Oman, 2023;Van Dam et al., 2017) and in the light of existing studies with randomised designs that have shown interventions labelled mindfulness to be more effective only due to that label (Davies et al., 2022;Ghanbari Noshari et al., 2023). The manipulation check suggested people did read the adverts: participants in the mindfulness condition rated the programme to contain mindfulness to a greater extent. If these results are replicated, it would suggest there is little marketing benefit to labelling a programme as containing mindfulness. Perhaps MBPs have passed their peak of inflated expectations, to use Gartner hype cycle terminology (Fenn & Raskino, 2008), and could be heading to disillusionment.

The lack of mindfulness hype effect could encourage a more nuanced communication on the range of techniques and mechanisms that can be used to improve wellbeing. There is a need to improve terminology when talking about wellbeing programmes to clarify their underlying mechanistic differences. Currently, despite the efforts to consolidate the definition of mindfulness-based programmes (notably, Crane et al., 2017), the term is loosely used in practice as well as research (Galante & Van Dam, 2024;Van Dam et al., 2017). Scientists and the general public alike often have no reliable source of information to distinguish programmes that are mindfulness-based due to their theoretical underpinnings from those that don the label solely for marketing purposes.

The lack of uncertainty effect, whereby communicating the uncertainty around the effectiveness of the programme did not reduce the rated likelihood of joining the programme, corroborates previous findings from the context of avoiding negative consequences (e.g., Gustafson & Rice, 2019). Gustafson and Rice demonstrated that presenting uncertainty did not adversely affect participants' beliefs, behavioural intentions nor the perceived credibility of the data. They argue that these results should encourage scientists to convey uncertainty when discussing evidence of risk of negative events, as it increases accuracy and ethics in scientific communication. Still, the lack of effect observed here could be due to the way uncertainty is represented in our study -numerically. It has been previously proposed (Reyna & Brainerd, 1995) that a numerical percentage is more concrete and thus likely to be interpreted as exact, relative to a verbal probability which conveys the chances of improvement as 'modest' or 'likely'. Indeed, prior work has demonstrated significant differences between numeric and non-numeric presentation of the benefits of a medicine on willingness to take that medication (Blalock et al., 2016). Verbal representations of uncertainty (as opposed to numeric) can mean different people understand them differently (Budescu et al., 2009), thus future work should consider how numeric and word-based presentation of effects might differentially influence audience interpretation. Our results underscore the need for careful and balanced science communication. Despite a well-established framework to convey the quality of evidence of health interventions (Guyatt et al., 2008), this study provides little evidence to suggest communicating uncertainty or ambiguity is an effective way to deter people from signing up to programmes with inflated promises of benefits.

Balanced public communication that transparently considers uncertainty and at the same time increases the likelihood of taking up evidence-based treatments and programmes is a challenge. Lay research summaries are often brief in the interest of attracting attention and therefore cannot contain lengthy instructions on interpreting uncertainty or establishing the theoretical underpinnings of the intervention in question. There are promising avenues to making it easier for the public to evaluate the quality of promotional claims. One is to use publicly regulated heuristics, such as labelling or traffic-light systems that colour-code risk.

While these could work in some contexts (e.g., Crockett et al., 2018), there is also evidence that these approaches in other settings could be ineffective (Vasiljevic et al., 2015) or counter-effective (Gómez et al., 2016). Another approach is to teach the public to notice the hallmarks of inflated benefits (e.g., psychological inoculation approaches) although these have been mainly studied in the context of misinformation (Traberg et al., 2022).

div.head: Limitations
div.p: These results should be interpreted with customary caution as for any hypothetical online experiments. We received responses from suspected bots and those who repeatedly took part in the experiment. We did our best to detect these using available tools provided by Qualtrics and Prolific. Additionally, we did not ask people to join a programme. Therefore, people's actual behaviour may differ from what they plan to do. Furthermore, we collected little information on the representativeness of the sample to employees' or wider population in general. As discussed, the lack of effect of conveying uncertainty could be due to the way in which uncertainty was presented (numerically, as part of a longer text). Therefore, the lack of effect could be a false negative.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: The results presented in this paper, if confirmed elsewhere, suggest there is little marketing benefit to label a programme to contain mindfulness. We encourage public consideration of a wider range of interventions, given that there is no evidence that mindfulness-based programmes are more effective than other interventions, particularly when delivered in the workplace (Galante et al., 2021;Vainre et al., 2024). Furthermore, there is much potential to improve discussions on mindfulness-based programmes and other wellbeing programmes and their effectiveness, and to investigate their mechanisms of action. There is a need to better understand how to communicate the uncertainty around intervention effectiveness so that members of the public as well as commissioners of these programmes for organisations (such as human resources representatives) can have realistic expectations regarding the likely outcomes.

figure.figDesc: The experiment featured a 2 (Intervention type: Mindfulness-based wellbeing programme, Wellbeing programme) x 2 (Uncertainty of the effect: Presented, Not presented) betweensubjects design. Ethical approval was received from the Human Research Ethics Committee of The University of Melbourne (2023-25777-36625-3). The experiment was preregistered on Open Science Framework (osf.io/6vtxd).

figure.head: FIGURE 2 .
figure.figDesc: Number of Participants at Recruitment, Randomisation, and Analysis.Across the whole sample, more than half (n = 378, 56.84%) reported to not have previously participated in a workplace-based self-improvement, health, or wellbeing program. Of those who had (n = 286, 43.01%), the most common type of program was mindfulness (n = 155), followed by stress or time-management program (n = 145), and physical exercise program (n = 111).Overall, participants rated a mean of 31 (out of 100; SD = 25.69) for how common mindfulness practice was in their community. Participants' lifetime experience with mediation was low. Two-thirds (n = 409, 61.50%) of participants reported 0-10 hours of prior meditation, 168 (25.26%) had meditated between 11-100 hours, 48 (7.21%) reported 101-500 hours of meditation, 17 (2.56%) reported 501-1000 hours, 15 (2.26%) reported 1001-5000
